source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: In-reactor stress-relaxation tests were done on zirconium alloys with different compositions, grain sizes, heat-tratments, cold-work, and specimen stress directions at $5 6 8 \pm 5 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ in a fast neutron flux $( \mathbf { E } > \mathsf { I } \ \mathbf { M } \mathbf { e } \mathbf { V } )$ of $2 . 0 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 7 }$ neutrons $( \boldsymbol { \mathsf { n } } ) / \mathsf { m } ^ { 2 } \boldsymbol { \mathsf { s } } ,$ for up to $8 2 0 0 \ \mathrm { h }$ with initial stresses up to $3 0 0 \ \mathsf { M P a }$

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: initial stresses up to $3 0 0 \ \mathsf { M P a }$

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: The effects of the metallurgical variables on the in-reactor stress relaxation of zirconium alloys is small. Variations in composition and heat-treatments change the relaxation rate constant by factors of 2 to 4, while variatons due to cold-work and working direction change the constant by factors of up to 2.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_025_chunk1
evidence_span: Stress-relieving (or aging) following cold-work decreases the initial stress drop.
